revisions.rev:
[[Image:GURPS Layers.jpg|frame|A rough breakdown of [[GURPS]] books. Bottom tier are core books necessary to play, moving up to least necessary.
Using resources from further up the stack requires less preparation work on the part of the game master.]] '''List of GURPS books''' is a listing of the publications from [[Steve Jackson Games]] and other licensed publishers for the [[GURPS]] [[role-playing game]].
==Fourth Edition== ===Core books=== These are the books necessary to play, with the core rules used in all settings (''GURPS Basic Set: Characters'' and ''Campaigns''), plus basic accessories.
; ''GURPS Basic Set: Characters''<ref>{{cite book |title=[[GURPS 4e Basic Set|GURPS Basic Set: Characters]] |series=GURPS 4E |first1=Steve |last1=Jackson |authorlink1=Steve Jackson (US game designer) |first2=Sean M. |last2=Punch |authorlink2=Sean Punch |first3=David L. |last3=Pulver |authorlink3=David Pulver |year=2004 |isbn=1-55634-729-4 |id=SJ01-0001 |publisher=Steve Jackson Games |location=Austin, Tex.}}</ref>
; ''GURPS Basic Set: Campaigns''<ref>{{cite book |title=[[GURPS 4e Basic Set|GURPS Basic Set: Campaigns]] |series=GURPS 4E |first1=Steve |last1=Jackson |authorlink1=Steve Jackson (US game designer) |first2=Sean M. |last2=Punch |authorlink2=Sean Punch |first3=David L. |last3=Pulver |authorlink3=David Pulver |year=2004 |isbn=978-1-55634-730-6 |id=SJ01-0002 |publisher=Steve Jackson Games |location=Austin, Tex.}}</ref>
; ''GURPS Basic Set Deluxe Edition''<ref>{{cite book |title=GURPS Basic Set Deluxe Edition |series=GURPS 4E |first1=Steve |last1=Jackson |authorlink1=Steve Jackson (US game designer) |first2=Sean M. |last2=Punch |authorlink2=Sean Punch |first3=David L. |last3=Pulver |authorlink3=David Pulver |year=2004 |id=SJ01-0003}}</ref> : Limited, luxury edition ("bound in bonded leather with two-color foil stamping. They have buckram-textured endpapers and sewn head and foot bands") of the two volumes of the Basic Set.
; ''GURPS Lite''<ref>{{cite book |title=GURPS Lite |series=GURPS 4E |last1=Haring |first1=Scott |last2=Punch |first2=Sean |authorlink2=Sean Punch |year=2004 |url=http://www.sjgames.com/gurps/lite/ |id=SJ01-1004}}</ref> : A 32-page introduction to the rules of GURPS based on the core rules in the ''GURPS 4e Basic Set'' (mainly ''Characters''). It includes basic [[character creation]] with [[advantage (role-playing games)|advantage]]s, disadvantages, [[skill (role-playing games)|skill]]s and equipment, as well as some rules for playing. It is freely available, as a [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] from the Steve Jackson Games website, and a supplement to some GURPS books.
; ''GURPS Ultra-Lite''
; ''GURPS GM's Screen''
; ''GURPS Update'' : The official conversion guide from 3rd to 4th edition, released as a free PDF file and together with the GM's Screen
===Rules supplements=== These books detail general rules not used in all possible campaign, such as rules for magic spells, for superpowers and for martial arts.
; ''GURPS Magic''<ref>{{cite book |title=GURPS Magic |series=GURPS 4E |first1=Jackson |last1=Steve |authorlink1=Steve Jackson |first2=S. John |last2=Ross |authorlink2=S. John Ross (writer) |first3=Daniel U. |last3=Thibault |year=2006 |isbn=1-55634-733-2 |id=SJG01-0101 |publisher=Steve Jackson Games}}</ref> : [[magic (game)|Magic]] rules from the Basic set are expanded, detailing a large number of spells, and rules for alternative magic systems, magic item creation, alchemy etc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rpg.net/reviews/archive/11/11086.phtml |title=Review of GURPS Magic |work=[[RPGnet]] |date=March 24, 2006 |accessdate=2008-12-25}}</ref>
; ''GURPS Martial Arts''<ref>{{cite book |title=GURPS Martial Arts |series=GURPS 4E |last1=Punch |first1=Sean |authorlink1=Sean Punch |first2=Peter |last2=Dell'Orto |year=2008 |isbn=978-1-55634-762-7 |id=SJG01-0105 |publisher=Steve Jackson Games}}</ref> : Includes new perks, skills, techniques, styles, weapons, and extended combat and injury rules, as well as history on the martial arts, pregenerated NPCs, and ideas for martial-arts campaigns.
; ''GURPS Mass Combat'' (PDF): gives rules for large-scale battles between military units, as well as allowing for the actions of player characters.
; ''GURPS Powers''<ref>{{cite book |title=GURPS Powers |series=GURPS 4E |first1=Sean |last1=Punch |authorlink1=Sean Punch |first2=Phil |last2=Masters |year=2007 |isbn=1-55634-742-1 |id=SJG01-0102 |publisher=Steve Jackson Games |location=Austin, Tex.}}</ref> : Extends the basic character creation rules to better handle high powered characters, and allow highly detailed customization of powers in which each power consists of a range of abilities (ie, advantages) and a talent, with a "source" and a "focus", adding color and helping to tie together the abilities, and an additional "power modifier" that acts like an enhancement (rare) or limitation to the power as a whole.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rpg.net/reviews/archive/11/11886.phtml | title = Review of GURPS Powers}}</ref>
; ''GURPS Thaumatology''<ref>{{cite book |title=GURPS Thaumatology |series=GURPS 4E |first=Phil |last=Masters |year=2008 |isbn=978-1-55634-758-0 |id=SJG01-0107 |publisher=Steve Jackson Games}}</ref> : Extends further the rules about magic, adding ceremonial, spirit, runic, freeform, material (alchemy, herbalism), and real-world-inspired magic.
===Genre toolkits=== These books describe how to design and play campaigns in a particular [[genre]], such as [[fantasy]], [[science fiction]] or [[detective fiction]]. *{{Gurps book | title=GURPS Fantasy | author=William H. Stoddard | year=2006<sup>3</sup> | isbn=1-55634-519-4 }} - This toolkit covers creation of different types of [[fantasy]] settings include "[[High fantasy|High]]" and "[[Low fantasy|Low]]", "[[Dark fantasy|Dark]]" and "Light", [[Swords and Sorcery]], and Myth; it also covers typical fantasy races and non-standard settings, such as "Roma Arcana", based on a fantastical Rome that never completely fell. It was a nominee at the 2005 [[Origins Award]] for Best Roleplaying Game.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.gamingreport.com/article.php?sid=16417&mode=&order=0|title= Origins Awards 2005 Announcement|accessdate=2007-08-24}}</ref> *{{Gurps book | title=GURPS Mysteries | author=Lisa Steele | year=2006 | isbn=1-55634-761-8 }} - A [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] file and [[Print on demand|POD]] release about [[detective fiction]] based adventures and campaigns, crime scenes, and advanced rules for interrogating [[Non-player character|NPC]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enworld.org/reviews.php?do=review&reviewid=2267428|title=Review of GURPS Mysteries}} Review at ENWorld; {{cite web|url=http://www.ogrecave.com/features/12xmas_2005_4.shtml|title=Christmas Gift Guide 2005}} Brief review at OgreCave.com</ref> *{{Gurps book | title=[[GURPS Space]] | author=Jon F. Zeigler and James L. Cambias | year=2006<sup>4</sup> | isbn=1-55634-245-4 }} - Covers the planning and running of [[science fiction]] campaigns with special emphasis on the creation of star systems, worlds and alien races.<ref name=Schick/> *{{Gurps book | title=GURPS Supers | author=William H. Stoddard | year= | isbn=978-1-55634-771-9 }} - Builds on ''GURPS Powers'' to describe powers, rules, and guidelines to run a [[superhero]] campaign.<ref name=Schick/>
===Fictional settings=== These supplements details how to design and play campaigns set in particular fictional settings, either specific to GURPS (such as "Banestorm", a fantasy setting, or "Infinite Worlds", about exploration of [[Parallel universe (fiction)|parallel universe]]s) or independent of it (such as the ''[[Star Trek]]'' universe). *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Banestorm | author=Phil Masters and Jonathan Woodward | year=2005 | isbn=1-55634-744-8 }}, detailing a fantasy setting called Yrth in which standard fantasy tropes such as Wizards, Orcs, Elves, Dwarves are present, along with more unusual fantastic races like the Reptile Men. A basic premise of the setting is that magical ''banestorms'' pick up people, whole villages, etc. from other worlds (including Earth) and deposit them on Yrth.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rpg.net/reviews/archive/11/11725.phtml | title=Review of GURPS Banestorm}} Comprehensive review at [[RPGnet]]</ref> *''Changing Times'' (PDF) updates the rules of the [[Transhuman Space]] setting for compatibility with GURPS 4th edition. *{{gurps book | title=[[GURPS Infinite Worlds]] | author=Kenneth Hite, Steve Jackson, and John M. Ford | year=2005 | isbn=1-55634-734-0 }}, winner of the 2005 Origins Award for Best Roleplaying Supplement.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.originsgames.com/awards/2005 | title=2005 List of Winners}}</ref> Describes play in two settings, Infinite Worlds (cross-world travel, including other published GURPS settings) and Time Travel (within Earth's history). *''GURPS Traveller: Interstellar Wars'' - Describing a period of the history of the [[science fiction]] ''[[Traveller (role-playing game)|Traveller]]'' setting, early in its history; includes rules for generating characters for the setting, starship design, interstellar trade, exploration, and ship-to-ship combat. *''GURPS Casey and Andy'' (PDF) - A setting inspired by the [[Casey and Andy]] webcomic by Andy Weir *''GURPS Lands Out of Time'' (PDF) - A setting that pits man against dinosaur. *''GURPS Prime Directive'' - One of the incarnations of the [[Prime Directive (role-playing game)|Prime Directive]] role-playing game, set in the ''[[Star Trek]]''-derived [[Star Fleet Universe]], together with its sourcebooks: **''GURPS Prime Directive: Klingons'' **''GURPS Prime Directive: Romulans'' *{{nihongo|''GURPS Reborn Rebirth''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãªãã¼ã³ãªãã¼ã¹ã}} ({{nihongo|Shou Tomono|[[:ja:åéè©³|åéè©³]]}}, {{nihongo|Tadaaki Kawahito|å·äººå¿ æ}} and [[Group SNE]], 2006, in [[Japanese language|Japanese]], ISBN 4-903177-19-X) A few years ago [[world tree]]s appeared all around the world, producing guardian spirits named [[Yuurei]] (lit. ghost) and interfering with real world events. Set in contemporary Japan. Published by {{nihongo|Hobby Base|[[:ja:ããã¼ãã¼ã¹|ããã¼ãã¼ã¹]]}}. *{{nihongo|''[[GURPS Runal|GURPS Yuel]]''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ã¦ã¨ã«ã}} in Japanese) *''Girl Genius RPG'' (in production),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sjgames.com/gurps/books/girlgenius/ |title=The Girl Genius RPG}}</ref> based on the ''[[Girl Genius]]'' webcomic by [[Studio Foglio]] *''GURPS Thaumatology: Alchemical Baroque'' - An updated alchemy magic setting that originally appeared in GURPS All-Star Jam 2004. * ''GURPS Martial Arts: Gladiators'' * ''GURPS Gun Fu'' * ''GURPS Locations: Metro of Madness'' * ''GURPS Hot Spots: Renaissance Florence'' * ''Vorkosigan Saga Sourcebook and Roleplaying Game'' - the sourcebook of [[Lois McMaster Bujold]]'s [[Vorkosigan Saga]].
===Technology and equipment=== These handbooks describe the data, in terms of GURPS, of specific objects, gadgets and vehicles, and how to construct new ones. *''[[GURPS Bio-Tech]]'' - describes medical techniques and enhancements, and modified life forms. *''GURPS Low-Tech'' - describes technologies and inventions up through the [[Age of Sail]]. *''GURPS High-Tech''.<ref name=Schick/> - describes technologies from the invention of gunpowder to the present day. *''GURPS Ultra-Tech'' - describes technologies from the near future onwards. *''GURPS Shell-Tech'' (PDF) - gives more cybershell designs for Transhuman Space. *''GURPS Vehicle Design'' (forthcoming) *''GURPS Armorer Handbook'' (concept considered for release)
===Spaceships===
These handbooks give a streamlined method for spacecraft construction and combat.
*''GURPS Spaceships'' (PDF) - describes the basic design and combat system. *''GURPS Spaceships 2: Traders, Liners, and Transports'' (PDF) - concentrates on the economics of merchant spacecraft. *''GURPS Spaceships 3: Warships and Space Pirates'' (PDF) *''GURPS Spaceships 4: Fighters, Carriers, and Mecha'' (PDF) *''GURPS Spaceships 5: Exploration and Colony Spacecraft'' (PDF) *''GURPS Spaceships 6: Mining and Industrial Spacecraft'' (PDF) *''GURPS Spaceships 7: Strange and Alien Spacecraft'' (PDF) *''GURPS Spaceships 8: Transhuman Spacecraft'' (PDF) - spacecraft taken from the Transhuman Space setting
===Creatures=== These handbooks describe the data, in terms of GURPS, of monsters and creatures, mostly from myths. *''GURPS Creatures of the Night, Volume 1'' (PDF) *''GURPS Creatures of the Night, Volume 2'' (PDF) *''GURPS Creatures of the Night, Volume 3'' (PDF) *''GURPS Creatures of the Night, Volume 4'' (PDF) *''GURPS Creatures of the Night, Volume 5'' (PDF) *''GURPS Dragons'' (3rd Edition with 4th Edition appendix)
===Dungeon Fantasy series=== These handbooks describe how to reduce GURPS to the essential abilities and rules you need to play in a typical Medieval Fantasy "Dungeon Crawl" type of game. *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 1: Adventurers '' *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 2: Dungeons'' *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 3: The Next Level'' *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 4: Sages'' *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 5: Allies'' (PDF) *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 6: 40 Artifacts'' (PDF) *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 7: Clerics'' (PDF) *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 8: Treasure Tables'' (PDF) *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 9: Summoners'' (PDF) *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 10: Taverns'' (PDF) *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 11: Power-Ups'' (PDF) *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 12: Ninjas'' (PDF) *''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy Monsters 1'' (PDF)
===Action series=== These supplements describe how to reduce GURPS to the essential abilities and rules you need to play in games inspired by action movies of the 1980s and beyond. *''GURPS Action 1: Heroes '' (PDF) *''GURPS Action 2: Exploits'' (PDF) *''GURPS Action 3: Furious Fists'' (PDF)
===Power-Ups series=== These supplements add a small set of new abilities for characters. *''GURPS Power-Ups 1: Imbuements'' (PDF) *''GURPS Power-Ups 2: Perks'' (PDF)
===Monster Hunters series === These handbooks describe how to reduce GURPS to the essential abilities and rules you need to play in a typical modern "Monster Hunting" type of game. Example settings include ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'', or Charles Stross's ''The Laundry'' series.
*''GURPS Monster Hunters 1: Champions'' (PDF) *''GURPS Monster Hunters 2: The Mission'' (PDF) *''GURPS Monster Hunters 3: The Enemy'' (PDF) *''GURPS Monster Hunters 4: Sidekicks'' (PDF)
==Third Edition (and previous editions)== ===Core books=== *''GURPS Basic Set, First Edition: Characters'' *''GURPS Basic Set, First Edition: Campaigns'' *''GURPS Basic Set, Second Edition: Characters'' *''GURPS Basic Set, Second Edition: Campaigns'' *''GURPS Basic Set, Third Edition'', winner of the 1988 [[Origins Award]] for Best Roleplaying Rules.<ref name="1988awards"/> *''GURPS Basic Set, Third Edition'' (Revised) *''GURPS Compendium I'' *''GURPS Compendium II'' *''GURPS Lite'' *''Man to Man: Fantasy Combat from GURPS'', a boardgame of melee combat, using the combat rules from ''GURPS''. Published in 1985, before the ''GURPS'' system.<ref>Published in 1985, the year prior to GURPS Basic Set First Edition. http://rpggeek.com/rpgitem/45686/gurps-basic-set-first-edition http://rpggeek.com/rpgitem/50272/man-to-man </ref>
===Rules supplements=== *''GURPS All-Star Jam 2004'' *''GURPS Best Of Pyramid 1'' - First selection of articles from online gaming magazine [[Pyramid (magazine)|Pyramid]]. *''GURPS Best Of Pyramid 2'' *''GURPS Grimoire'' - A companion volume for ''GURPS Magic'', describing hundreds of spells and two new Colleges, Gates and Techs. *''GURPS Magic'' (for GURPS 3e) *''GURPS Martial Arts'' (for GURPS 3e) *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Psionics | edition=1st Edition | author=Pulver, David | year=1995 | isbn=1-55634-196-2 }} *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Religion: Gods, Priestly Powers and Cosmic Truths | edition=1st Edition | author=Naylor, Janet | year=1994 | isbn=1-55634-2020-0 }}
===Characters=== *''GURPS Aliens'', a collection of alien races.<ref name=Schick>{{cite book | first=Lawrence | last=Schick | year=1991 | title=Heroic Worlds: A History and Guide to Role-Playing Games | publisher=Prometheus Books | location=Buffalo, New York | isbn=0-87975-653-5 }}</ref> *''GURPS Fantasy Folk'', a collection of fantasy races.<ref name=Schick/> *''GURPS Monsters'', a collection of 48 monstrous characters including [[Tiamat]], [[Bigfoot]], [[Dracula]], and original creations *''GURPS Rogues'' *''GURPS Supporting Cast'' *''GURPS Villains'' *''GURPS Warriors'' *''GURPS Who's Who 1'', a collection of 52 historical characters including [[Aristotle]], [[Aaron Burr]], [[Julius Caesar]], [[William Shakespeare]], and [[Nikola Tesla]] *''GURPS Who's Who 2'', a collection of 56 more historical characters *''GURPS Wizards''
===Creatures=== *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Bestiary | edition=1st Edition | author=O'Sullivan, Steffan; Evans, Mark | year=1988 | isbn=1-55634-087-7 }}, containing information and statistics for animals, including information to play animals as player character.<ref name=Schick/> *''GURPS Blood Types'', containing biographies and gaming statistics for 23 [[vampire]]s and vampire-like beings, and guidelines on creating more for various campaign settings. *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Creatures of the Night | edition=1st Edition | author=Maykrantz, Scott Paul | year=1994 | isbn=1-55634-273-X }}, describing original "modern horrors" (such as "Grue Beetles", "Netherpunks" and "Slitherwens"). *''GURPS Dinosaurs'', giving game data for dinosaurs. *''GURPS Dragons'' (3rd Edition with 4th Edition appendix), giving game information and data about dragons, also as player characters. *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Faerie | edition=1st Edition | author=Davis, Graeme | year=2003 | isbn=1-55634-632-8 }}, giving character templates and campaign settings for adventures involving the [[Little people (mythology)|Little people]]. *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Bestiary | edition=1st Edition | author=O'Sullivan, Steffan | year=1999 | isbn=1-55634-184-9 }}, describing several fantasy animals and plants.<ref name=Schick/> *''GURPS Shapeshifters'', about creation rules, game environments and sample characters for [[werewolf|werewolves]], [[DoppelgÃ¤nger]]s and other [[shapeshifting|shapeshifters]]. *''GURPS Space Bestiary'', describing many fictional extraterrestrial creatures, including silicon-based, crystalline, energy and liquid beings. *''GURPS Spirits'', a guide to fictional spirits from several cultures (angels, demons, djinn, dryads, ghosts etc.), with a possible system of spirit-based magic. *''GURPS Undead'', describing several kinds of [[undead]] creatures (vampires, zombies etc.), with rules to create more and related topics.
===Technology and equipment=== *''GURPS Bio-Tech'' (for the 3e) *''GURPS High-Tech'' (for the 3e) *''GURPS Low-Tech'' (for the 3e) *''GURPS Magic Items 1'' *''GURPS Magic Items 2'' *''GURPS Magic Items 3'' *''GURPS Modern Firepower'' *''GURPS Robots'' *''GURPS Steam-Tech'' *''GURPS Ultra-Tech 1'' *''GURPS Ultra-Tech 2'' *''GURPS Vehicles'' *''GURPS Vehicles Expansion 1'' *''GURPS Vehicles Expansion 2'' *''GURPS Vehicles Lite'' *''GURPS Warehouse 23''
===Genre toolkits=== *{{Gurps book | title=GURPS Atomic Horror | author=Paul Elliott and Chris McCubbin | year=2001<sup>2</sup> | publisher= | language= | isbn=1-55634-533-X }} - A sourcebook for running campaigns inspired by [[B-movie|B-grade]] [[science fiction]] and [[horror film|horror]] movies of the 1950s.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rpg.net/news+reviews/reviews/rev_5209.html | title=GURPS Atomic Horror 2nd Edition}} RPGnet review</ref> *{{Gurps book | title=GURPS Autoduel | author=Christopher J. Burke and Rob Garitta | year=1997<sup>2</sup> | publisher= | language= | isbn=1-55634-240-3 }} - Describes a post-apocalyptic setting also shared by the ''[[Car Wars]]'' boardgame and the ''[[Autoduel]]'' computer game in which characters are involved in ''autoduelling'', combat in armed and armored motor vehicles. The sourcebook contains rules for designing vehicles, additional skills used by autoduellist characters, and new technology and social conditions of the world. The setting is extended in an additional set of sourcebooks for the Autoduel world (see below).<ref name=Schick/> *{{Gurps book | title=GURPS Autoduel: Car Warriors | author=Martha and David Ladyman | year=?</sup> | publisher= | language= | isbn=1-55634-081-8 }} - Pre-generated characters for ''GURPS Autoduel''.<ref name=Schick/> *{{Gurps book | title=GURPS Cliffhangers | author=Brian J. Underhill | year=1989, 2002<sup>2</sup> | publisher= | language= | isbn=1-55634-589-5 }} - Sourcebook with background material and rules for adventure tale in the style of 1920s and 1930s [[Pulp magazine|pulp fiction]].<ref name=Schick/> *{{Gurps book | title=GURPS Cops | author=Lisa J. Steele | year=2002 | publisher= | language= | isbn=1-55634-458-9 }} - A sourcebook to create realistic police officer characters and adventures. *''GURPS Covert Ops'' *''[[GURPS Cyberpunk]]'' <!--([[1990]]; 1995, 4th printing)--> *''GURPS Espionage'' *''GURPS Horror''.<ref name=Schick/> *''GURPS Illuminati'', describing the secret societies/conspiracies genre, building on the ''[[Illuminati (game)|Illuminati]]'' card game, in its turn inspired by [[Robert Shea]] and [[Robert Anton Wilson]]'s ''[[The Illuminatus! Trilogy]]''. Winner of the 1992 Origins Award for Best Roleplaying Supplement.<ref name="1992awards">{{cite web|url=http://www.originsgames.com/awards/1992|title=1992 List of Winners}}</ref><ref name="lhomme">{{cite journal | last=Lhomme | first=Tristan | title=Pour GURPS, en V.O. - GURPS Illuminati - Imperial Rome | journal=Casus Belli | issue=70 | pages=18 | date= JulyâAugust 1992}} Review {{fr icon}}</ref> *''GURPS Mars'' *''GURPS Mecha'' *''[[GURPS Space]]'' (for the 3e), winner of the 1988 Origins Award for Best Roleplaying Supplement.<ref name="1988awards">{{cite web|url=http://www.originsgames.com/awards/1988|title=1988 List of Winners}}</ref> *''GURPS Special Ops'' *''GURPS Steampunk'', winner of the 2000 Origins Award for Best Roleplaying Supplement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.originsgames.com/awards/2000|title=2000 List of Winners}}</ref> *''GURPS Supers'' *''GURPS SWAT'' *''GURPS Time Travel'', winner of the 1991 Origins Award for Best Roleplaying Supplement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.originsgames.com/awards/1991|title=1991 List of Winners}}</ref>
===History and culture=== *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Age of Napoleon | author=Nicholas Caldwell; William H Stoddard | year=2003 | isbn=1-55634-451-1}}, background for adventuring set in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, with character write-ups for such celebrities of the era as Catherine the Great (of Russia) and George Washington as well as Napoleon's crowd. *''GURPS Arabian Nights'' *''GURPS Atlantis'' *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Aztecs | author=Aurelio Locsin III | year=1993 | isbn=1-55634-260-8}}, Mexico before Cortez. *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Camelot | author=Robert M. Schroeck; Peggy Schroeck | year=1991 | isbn=1556341997 }}, fantasy role-playing in the Arthurian genre.<ref>{{cite book | first=John | last=Clute | coauthors=Grant, John | year=1999 | title=The Encyclopedia of Fantasy | publisher=Macmillan | isbn=0312198698 }}</ref> *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Celtic Myth | author=Ken and Jo Walton; | year=1995 | isbn=1-55634-260-8}}, Once Celts raided, looted, conquered and settled over thousands of miles, leaving red-haired descendents from Ireland to Spain to Poland to Turkey, coming within a sword's width of extinguishing the Roman empire before it was born. They left behind rich and terrible mythos, of head-hunting and of poetry, and, of course, of the Fair Folk, a euphemism in the same vein as the Greeks used when they referred to the Furies as "the kindly ones." *''GURPS China'' *''GUPRS Egypt'' *''GURPS Greece'' *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Ice Age | author=Kirk Wilson Tate | year=1989 | isbn=1-55634-134-2 }}, <!-- was wikilinked, now redirected to this list --> describing rules and setting for role-playing in the time of prehistoric man, including a shamanic magic system. *''GURPS Imperial Rome'', describing the historical background and adventure ideas for roleplaying in ancient [[Rome]], including a [[parallel universe (fiction)|parallel universe]] where Roman Empire survived till today.<ref name="lhomme"/> *''GURPS Japan''.<ref name=Schick/> *''GURPS Middle Ages I'', <!-- was wikilinked, now redirected to this list --> a [[sourcebook]] for running a [[Middle Ages]] themed ''[[GURPS]]'' campaign. *''GURPS Old West'' *''GURPS Places of Mystery'' *''GURPS Robin Hood'' *''GURPS Russia'' *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Scarlet Pimpernel | author=Robert Traynor & Lisa Evans | year=1992 | isbn=1-55634-212-8 }}, details for playing in the milieu of the [[Scarlet Pimpernel]] books set in 18th century Revolutionary France, by [[Baroness Orczy]]. *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Swashbucklers: Roleplaying in the World of Pirates and Musketeers | author=Steffan O'Sullivan | year=1990 | isbn=1-55634-394-9 }}, detailed 17th century role-play in the [[swashbuckler]] genre, with rules for ship combat, fencing, guns, dueling, codes of honor and so forth.<ref name=Schick/> *''GURPS Timeline'', <!-- was wikilinked, now redirected to this list --> a source book with a timeline for play and many short articles, some of which describe "Lost Continents" and some tales about "Lost Fortunes". *''GURPS Vikings''
===Fictional Settings=== *''AADA Road Atlas Volume 1: The East Coast'' - The first in a series of road atlases detailing the setting of ''GURPS Autoduel'' (see above). *''AADA Road Atlas Volume 2: The West Coast'' *''AADA Road Atlas Volume 3: The South'' *''AADA Road Atlas Volume 4: Australia'' *''AADA Road Atlas Volume 5: The Midwest'' *''AADA Road Atlas Volume 6: The Free Oil States'' *''AADA Road Atlas Volume 7: The Mountain West'' *''GURPS Alpha Centauri'', detailing the setting of the ''[[Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri]]'' computer game.<ref>{{cite book | last=Stenros | first=Jaakko | editor=Markus Montola and Jaakko Stenros | year=2004 | title=Beyond Role and Play: Tools, Toys and Theory for Harnessing the Imagination | url=http://www.ropecon.fi/brap/ch15.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate=2008-08-05 | publisher=Ropecon ry | isbn=952-91-6843-8 | chapter-url=Genre, Style, Method and Focus: Typologies for Role-Playing Games }}</ref> *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Alternate Earths | author=Kenneth Hite, Craig Neumeier, Michael S. Schiffer | year=1999 | isbn=1-55634-318-3 }}—presents six versions of Earth possessing [[Alternate history|alternate histories]] to that of our own world, as well as a number of less-detailed settings scattered throughout the book in sidebars: for instance, "Gernsback" is a parallel, inspired by 1930s [[science fiction]] adventure stories (it is named for the editor [[Hugo Gernsback]]) has as its point of divergence is the marriage of [[Nikola Tesla]] to Anne Morgan, daughter of banker and financier [[J. P. Morgan]]. Attention is given to the ways in which agents of the Infinity Patrol presented in ''GURPS Time Travel'' and their rivals from the mysterious parallel known as "Centrum" attempt to influence the course of history in each parallel; the concept of the conflict between the Infinity Patrol and Centrum across the many parallel Earths was made central to the Fourth Edition of ''GURPS'' as the default setting in the Basic Set and in the supplement ''[[GURPS Infinite Worlds]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.fantasylibrary.com/lounge/gurpalte.htm | title=Review:GURPS Alternate Earths}} Fantasy Lounge review</ref> *''[[GURPS Alternate Earths II]]'' presents six more alternate histories, among which that of Centrum, whose point of divergence is the successful crossing of the [[White Ship]], meaning that [[William Adelin]], the sole male heir of King [[Henry I of England]], was never drowned. *''GURPS Black Ops'', describing a setting that Earth under threat from various [[Extraterrestrial life in popular culture|alien]], [[supernatural]], and other monstrous powers, while the player characters are super-skilled agents of the clandestine agency "the Company", known as "Black Operatives" or "Black Ops"; the setting relies heavily on use of various known or less known [[urban legends]] and [[conspiracy theories]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rpg.net/news+reviews/reviews/rev_2671.html | title = GURPS Black Ops}} RPGnet review of ''GURPS Black Ops''</ref> *''GURPS Cabal'', a customizable setting depicting a modern-day [[secret society]] composed of [[vampire]]s, [[lycanthrope]]s and [[Sorcerer (person)|sorcerers]] who study the underlying principles of magic and visit other planes of existence. *''GURPS Callahan's Crosstime Saloon'', a [[Parallel universe (fiction)|parallel world]]-themed setting based in a bar/space nexus that was created by [[Spider Robinson]] in his ''[[Callahan's Crosstime Saloon]]'' stories. *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Conan | author=Curtis M. Scott | year=1995 | isbn=1-55634-148-2 }}—detailing the world in which the adventures of [[Robert E. Howard]]'s [[Conan the Barbarian]] are set.<ref name=Schick/> *''GURPS Cthulhupunk'' *''GURPS Cyberworld'' *''[[GURPS Discworld]]'' *''[[GURPS Discworld Also]]'' *''GURPS Fantasy'' *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Fantasy II: Adventures in the Mad Lands | author=Robin D. Laws | year=1993 | isbn=1556342640 }} *''GURPS Fantasy GM's Pack'' *''GURPS Fantasy Tredroy'' *''GURPS Fantasy Harkwood'' *''Hellboy Sourcebook and Roleplaying Game'', detailing the world in which the adventures of [[Hellboy]] are set. *''GURPS Goblins'', describing an original fantasy setting in a society of [[goblins]] in London in the 1830s. *''GURPS Horseclans'', detailing the [[Apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic science fiction|post-apocalyptic]] future described in the "[[Horseclans]]" science fiction series by [[Robert Adams (science fiction writer)|Robert Adams]]. *''GURPS Humanx'', detailing the [[Humanx Commonwealth]], the setting of a series of science fiction novels by [[Alan Dean Foster]].<ref name=Schick/> *''[[GURPS Illuminati University]]'', detailing a fictional college where absurdity and awful puns are the order of the day; its students range from witches and werewolves to secret agents and space aliens. *''GURPS Lensman'', detailing the setting of the [[Lensman|Lensman series]], a series of science fiction novels by [[E. E. Smith]]. *''GURPS New Sun'', detailing the setting of ''[[The Book of the New Sun]]'', a science fiction novel by [[Gene Wolfe]]. *''GURPS Myth'', detailing the setting of the ''[[Myth (computer game series)|Myth]]'' computer game. *''GURPS Planet Krishna'', detailing the setting of ''[[The Queen of Zamba]]'', a science fiction novel by [[L. Sprague de Camp]]. *''GURPS Planet of Adventure'', describing a distant world populated by many varied alien and half-alien races, set in the world of the ''[[Planet of Adventure]]'' series of novels by [[Jack Vance]]. *''GURPS Prime Directive'' (see above) *''GURPS Prime Directive: Klingons'' *''GURPS Prime Directive: Klingon Gunboat Deckplans'' *''GURPS Prime Directive: Module Prime Alpha'' *''GURPS Prisoner'', detailing the setting of the UK television series ''[[The Prisoner]]''.<ref name=Schick/> *''GURPS Reign of Steel'', describing a future world conquered by a conspiracy of [[artificial intelligence]]s, after a [[cybernetic revolt|robot revolt]] has concluded with the machines' victory.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rpg.net/news+reviews/reviews/rev_413.html | title=GURPS Reign of Steel}} RPGnet review</ref> *''GURPS Riverworld'', a setting in the fictional world described in the novels of the ''[[Riverworld]]'' series by [[Philip JosÃ© Farmer]]. This setting is an artificial planet where everyone who lived before a set date in history seems to have been resurrected.<ref name=Schick/> *''GURPS Screampunk'' *''GURPS Space Atlas'' *''GURPS Space Atlas 2: The Corporate Worlds'' *''GURPS Space Atlas 3: The Confederacy'' *''GURPS Space Atlas 4: Phoenix and Saga Sectors'' *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Technomancer | author=David Pulver | year=1998 | isbn=1-55634-359-0 }}, describing a setting and new rules in an alternative modern Earth where [[magic (game)|magic]] co-exists with [[technology]]. It was based on the premise that the [[Trinity (nuclear test)|Trinity atomic test]] ripped a hole in the fabric of space-time, triggering a tornado of magical energy. *''GURPS Terradyne'', a future history suitable for a [[hard science fiction]] campaign-in the tradition of stories by [[Robert A. Heinlein]], [[Lester Del Rey]] and [[Ben Bova]]-in which technology has moved man out into space and Terradyne, a space-based corporate state, dominates but does not have exclusive control of space-based industries. It was superseded by the ''[[Transhuman Space]]'' series which covers the same niche. *''GURPS Uplift'', based on the [[fictional universe]] envisioned by [[David Brin]] in his ''[[Uplift Universe]]'' series, where [[biological uplift]] of animals has become common. *''GURPS Voodoo'' *''GURPS War Against the Chtorr'', describing additional rules and a game setting based on the ''[[War Against the Chtorr]]'' science fiction novel series by [[David Gerrold]], which depicts an Earth invaded by an alien ecology. *{{gurps book | author=[[Sasha Miller]] and Ben W. Miller | year=1989 | title=GURPS Witch World | isbn=1-55634-143-1 }}—a setting based on the series of ''[[Witch World]]'' novels by [[Andre Norton]]. Included are a bestiary of Witch World creatures, details on the non-human races, a history and geography of the planet, and a color-based system of magic.<ref name=Schick/> *''GURPS Y2K'', detailing some possible scenarios involving the [[year 2000 problem]] and other world-changing events.
===Supers=== *''GURPS Aces Abroad'' *''GURPS I.S.T.: International Super Teams'' *''GURPS IST Kingston'' *''GURPS Mixed Doubles'', a collection of [[Non-player character|characters]] designed to be used with ''GURPS Supers''. *''GURPS Super Scum'' *''GURPS Supertemps'' *''GURPS Wild Cards'', detailing the setting of the science fiction/superhero shared universe [[Wild Cards]]<ref>{{cite journal | last=Syd | title=Wild Cards | journal=GamesMaster Magazine | volume=2 | issue=6 | pages=25 | month= February | year= 1990}} Review</ref>
===Transhuman Space=== *''[[Transhuman Space]]'' *''Broken Dreams'' *''Deep Beyond'' *''Fifth Wave'' *''High Frontier'' *''In The Well'' *''Orbital Decay'' *''Personnel Files'' *''Singapore Sling'' *''Spacecraft of the Solar System'' *''Toxic Memes'' *''Under Pressure''
===Traveller=== A set of books designed to allow game play in Traveller's Third [[Imperium (Traveller)|Imperium]] science-fiction setting using the ''GURPS'' rule system. [[Traveller (role-playing game)|Traveller]] was originally published in 1977 by [[Game Designers' Workshop]]. Steve Jackson Games also publishes online ''Journal of the Travellers' Aid Society'', the official magazine of ''Traveller''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://jtas.sjgames.com/ | title = Journal of the Travellers' Aid Society}}</ref> *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Traveller: Science Fiction Adventure in the Far Future | edition=2nd Edition | author=Wiseman, Loren | year=1998 | isbn=1-55634-408-2 }} *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Traveller: Alien Races 1 | author=Pulver, David L. | year=1998 | isbn=1-55634-361-2 }} provides details about the human-descended Zhodani and the alien Vargr, as well as three minor races. *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Traveller: Alien Races 2 | edition=1st Edition | author=Slack, Andy; Thomas, David; Pulver, David | year=1999 | isbn=1-55634-392-2 }} *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Traveller: Alien Races 3 | edition=1st Edition | author=Slack, Andy; Thomas, David; Pulver, David; Nilsen, David | year=2000 | isbn=1-55634-431-7 }} *{{gurps book | title=GURPS Traveller: Alien Races 4 | edition=1st Edition | author=Jackson, Steve; Wiseman, Loren | year=2001 | isbn=1-55634-433-3 }} *''GURPS Traveller: Behind the Claw'' *''GURPS Traveller: Deck Plan 1 Beowulf-Class Free Trader'' *''GURPS Traveller: Deck Plan 2 Modular Cutter'' *''GURPS Traveller: Deck Plan 3 Empress Marava-Class Far Trader'' *''GURPS Traveller: Deck Plan 4 Assault Cutter'' *''GURPS Traveller: Deck Plan 5 Sulieman-Class Scout/Courier'' *''GURPS Traveller: Deck Plan 6 Dragon-Class System Defense Boat'' *''GURPS Traveller: Droyne Coyn Set'' *''GURPS Traveller: Far Trader'' *''GURPS Traveller: First In'' *''GURPS Traveller: GM's Screen'' *''GURPS Traveller: Ground Forces'' *''GURPS Traveller: Heroes 1 - Bounty Hunters'' *''GURPS Traveller: Humaniti'' *''GURPS Traveller: Interstellar Wars'' (4e; see above) *''GURPS Traveller: Modular Cutter'' *''GURPS Traveller: Nobles'' *''GURPS Traveller: Planetary Survey 1 - Kamsii'' *''GURPS Traveller: Planetary Survey 2 - Denuli'' *''GURPS Traveller: Planetary Survey 3 - Granicus'' *''GURPS Traveller: Planetary Survey 4 - Glisten'' *''GURPS Traveller: Planetary Survey 5 - Tobibak'' *''GURPS Traveller: Planetary Survey 6 - Darkmoon'' *''GURPS Traveller: Psionics Institutes'' *''GURPS Traveller: Rim of Fire'' *''GURPS Traveller: Star Mercs'' *''GURPS Traveller: Starports'' *''GURPS Traveller: Starships'' *''GURPS Traveller: Sword Worlds''
===World War II=== *''GURPS WWII'' *''GURPS WWII: All the King's Men'' *''GURPS WWII: Hand of Steel'' *''GURPS WWII: Iron Cross'' *''GURPS WWII: Return to Honor'' *''GURPS WWII: Dogfaces'' *''GURPS WWII: Grim Legions'' *''GURPS WWII: Frozen Hell'' *''GURPS WWII: Weird War II'' *''GURPS WWII: Motor Pool''
===System conversions=== *''GURPS Blue Planet'' *{{gurps book | title=[[Bunnies & Burrows|GURPS Bunnies & Burrows]] | author=[[Steffan O'Sullivan]] | year=1992 | isbn=1-55634-237-3 }} Based on the novel ''[[Watership Down]]'', this setting uses animal characters with humans serving as an incomprehensible monster race. *''GURPS Castle Falkenstein'' **''GURPS Castle Falkenstein: The Ottoman Empire'' *''[[Conspiracy X|GURPS Conspiracy X]]'' *''GURPS Deadlands'' **''GURPS Deadlands: Hexes'' **''GURPS Deadlands: Varmints'' *''GURPS In Nomine'', the GURPS conversion of the ''[[In Nomine (role-playing game)|In Nomine]]'' roleplaying game *''GURPS Mage: The Ascension'', the GURPS conversion of the ''[[Mage: The Ascension]]'' roleplaying game *''GURPS Ogre'', a roleplaying version of the ''[[Ogre (game)|Ogre]]'' wargame *''GURPS Vampire: The Masquerade'', the GURPS conversion of the ''[[Vampire: The Masquerade]]'' roleplaying game. Winner of the 1993 Origins Award for Best Roleplaying Supplement.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.originsgames.com/awards/1993 | title=1993 List of Winners}}</ref> **''GURPS Vampire Companion'' *''GURPS Werewolf: The Apocalypse'', the GURPS conversion of the ''[[Werewolf: The Apocalypse]]'' roleplaying game
===Adventures=== *''GURPS Bili the Axe - Up Harzburk!'', a campaign of solo adventures set in Robert Adams's "Horseclans" universe (see above), in which the reader/player accompanies Bili the Axe on four years of Middle Kingdoms campaigning. The book was printed with a serious error in the numbering of the paragraphs, making it virtually impossible to play the adventure as designed, and so was recalled. *''GURPS Chaos in Kansas'' *''GURPS Conan and the Queen of the Black Coast'' *''GURPS Conan: Beyond Thunder River'' *''GURPS Conan: Moon of Blood'' *''GURPS Conan: The Wyrmslayer'' *''GURPS Cyberpunk Adventures'', winner of the 1992 Origins Award for Best Roleplaying Adventure.<ref name="1992awards"/> *''GURPS Deadlands Dime Novel 1: Aces and Eights'' *''GURPS Deadlands Dime Novel 2: Wanted: Undead or Alive'' *''GURPS Deathwish'' *''GURPS Fantasy Adventures'' *''GURPS Flight 13'' *''GURPS For Love of Mother-Not'' *''GURPS Martial Arts Adventures'' *''GURPS The Old Stone Fort'' *''GURPS Operation Endgame'' *''GURPS Orcslayer'' *''GURPS [[School of Hard Knocks (GURPS)|School of Hard Knocks]]'' (1989), originally written with support for the Champions 4th edition rules, but these rules were removed from the final printing. They were later published online. *''GURPS Space Adventures'' *''GURPS Space: Stardemon'' *''GURPS Supers Adventures'' *''GURPS Time Travel Adventures'' *''GURPS Space: Unnight'' *''GURPS Zombietown U.S.A.''
== Japanese products == Several books were produced in Japanese, mostly by the Japanese company [[Group SNE]], and published by various publishers. * Translations of ''GURPS'', 3rd (published by [[Kadokawa Shoten]]({{nihongo|Kadokawa Sneaker Bunko|[[:ja:è§å·ã¹ãã¼ã«ã¼æåº«|è§å·ã¹ãã¼ã«ã¼æåº«]]}} or {{nihongo|Kadokawa Sneaker G Bunko|[[:ja:è§å·ã¹ãã¼ã«ã¼ã»Gæåº«|è§å·ã¹ãã¼ã«ã¼ã»Gæåº«]]}}) ** {{nihongo|''GURPS Basic''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¼ã·ãã¯ã}} - Translation of ''GURPS Cyberpunk''. * Translations of ''GURPS'', 3rd (published by [[Fujimi Shobo]]) ** {{nihongo|''GURPS Basic kanyaku-ban''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¼ã·ãã¯å®è¨³çã}} - The ''complete translated version'' of {{nihongo|''GURPS Basic''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¼ã·ãã¯ã}} and the translation of ''GURPS Basic Set Third Edition, '''Revised''''' ** {{nihongo|''GURPS Magic kanyaku-ban''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¸ãã¯å®è¨³çã}} - The ''complete translated version'' of {{nihongo|''GURPS Magic''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¸ãã¯ã}} and the translation of ''GURPS Magic Second Edition'' for 3rd edition. *** {{nihongo|''GURPS Grimoire kanyaku-ban''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ã°ãªã¢ã¢å®è¨³çã}} - The translation of ''GURPS Grimoire''. ** {{nihongo|''GURPS Martial Arts kanyaku-ban''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¼ã·ã£ã«ã¢ã¼ãå®è¨³çã}} - The ''complete translated version'' of {{nihongo|''GURPS Martial Arts''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¼ã·ã£ã«ã¢ã¼ãã}} and the translation of ''GURPS Martial Arts Second Edition'' for 3rd edition. * {{nihongo|''GURPS Master Screen''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¹ã¿ã¼ã¹ã¯ãªã¼ã³ã}} - The {{nihongo|master screen|[[:ja:ãã¹ã¿ã¼ã¹ã¯ãªã¼ã³|ãã¹ã¿ã¼ã¹ã¯ãªã¼ã³]]}} for GURPS 3rd edition(published by [[Kadokawa Shoten]]). * Translations of ''GURPS'', 4th (published by [[Fujimi Shobo]]) ** {{nihongo|''GURPS Basic Dai-yon-han Character''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¼ã·ãã¯ãç¬¬4çãã­ã£ã©ã¯ã¿ã¼ã}} - The translation of ''GURPS Basic Set: Characters'' for Fourth Edition. ** {{nihongo|''GURPS Basic Dai-yon-han Campaign''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¼ã·ãã¯ãç¬¬4çãã­ã£ã³ãã¼ã³ã}} - The translation of ''GURPS Basic Set: Campaigns'' for Fourth Edition. ** {{nihongo|''GURPS Mahou-daizen''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»é­æ³å¤§å ¨ã}} - The translation of ''GURPS Magic'' for Fourth Edition. * {{nihongo|''GURPS Busin kourin''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¼ã·ã£ã«ã¢ã¼ãã»ã¢ããã³ãã£ã¼ æ­¦ç¥éè¨ã}} - [[Martial arts]]. The Supplement of ''GURPS Martial Arts''. * {{nihongo|''GURPS Cocoon''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ã³ã¯ã¼ã³ã}} - Comical fantasy and the parody of [[Sword World RPG]]. * {{nihongo|''GURPS Damned Stalkers''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»[[:ja:å¦é­å¤è¡|å¦é­å¤è¡]]ã ''Gurps Youma Yakou''}} - Modern horror. This supplement refers to ''GURPS Supers for Third Edition''. * {{nihongo|''GURPS The Damned Stalkers 2nd stage''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»[[:ja:å¦é­å¤è¡|ç¾é¬¼å¤ç¿]]ã ''Gurps Hyakki Yasyou''}} - The sequel to ''GURPS Youma Yakou''. This supplement refers to ''GURPS Supers for Third Edition'', ''GURPS Compendium I'' and ''GURPS Compendium II''. * {{nihongo|''GURPS Dragon Merc''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã©ã´ã³ãã¼ã¯ã}} - Crossover of multi-planes * {{nihongo|''GURPS Power up''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãã¯ã¼ã¢ããã}} * {{nihongo|''GURPS Ring Dream''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãªã³ã°â ããªã¼ã ã}} - Modern female [[Professional wrestling|wrestling]]<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sjgames.com/gurps/foreign.html | title = GURPS Around The World}}</ref> * {{nihongo|''GURPS RebornRebirth''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ãªãã¼ã³ãªãã¼ã¹ã}} - Written by [[Shou Tomono]]([[:ja:åéè©³|åéè©³]]), [[Tadaaki Kawahito]](å·äººå¿ æ) and Group SNE; published by {{nihongo|[[Hobby Base]]|[[:ja:ããã¼ãã¼ã¹|ããã¼ãã¼ã¹]]}} in [[2006]]: each [[player character]] possesses his own [[Yuurei]] (guardian spirit) and fights against bad Yuureis. * {{nihongo|''[[GURPS Runal]]/Yuel''|ãã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ã«ãã«ããã¬ã¼ãã¹ã»ã¦ã¨ã«ã}} - Written by Shou Tomono and Group SNE; published by Kadokawa Shoten in [[1992]]; "complete version" and ''GURPS Yuel'' published by [[Fujimi Shobo]] in [[1994]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://hiki.trpg.net/en/?Histrory | title = TRPG.NET Wiki for English - Chronological Table}}</ref> Several novels have been published based upon GURPS Runal,<ref>{{cite web|title=Search result of {{nihongo|Runal Saga|"ã«ãã«ã»ãµã¼ã¬"}} in Amazon.co.jp|url=http://www.amazon.co.jp/s/ref=nb_ss_fg_eng/250-2296602-2379429?__mk_ja_JP=%83J%83%5E%83J%83i&initialSearch=1&url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=%83%8B%83i%83%8B%81E%83T%81%5B%83K|accessdate=2007-08-31}}</ref> set in a fantasy world strongly influenced from [[RuneQuest]]: seven mysterious Moons grant magic power to their worshipers.
== Korean products == The Korean publisher Dayspring Games({{korean|ëìì¶í ì´ì¬ëª }}) published the Korean translation of ''GURPS'' and at least an original supplement, ''GURPS Sylfiena'', a fantasy setting.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sjgames.com/ill/archives.html?y=2008&m=March&d=3 | title = Steve Jackson Games Daily Illuminator - March 3, 2008}}</ref> * Translations of ''GURPS'', 3rd edition ** ''GURPS Gibon Set Gukmunpan'' ({{korean|GURPS ê¸°ë³¸ì¸í¸ êµ­ë¬¸í}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Basic Set'', 3rd edition ** ''GURPS Mabeop'' ({{korean|GURPS ë§ë²}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Magic'' for 3rd edition ** ''GURPS Mooye'' ({{korean|GURPS ë¬´ì}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Martial Arts'' for 3rd edition ** ''GURPS Fantasy'' ({{korean|GURPS ííì§}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Fantasy'' for 3rd edition ** ''GURPS Fantasy Jongjok'' ({{korean|GURPS ííì§ ì¢ ì¡±}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Fantasy Folk'' for 3rd edition ** ''GURPS Cyberpunk'' ({{korean|GURPS ì¬ì´ë²íí¬}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Cyberpunk'' for 3rd edition
* Translations of ''GURPS'', 4th edition ** ''GURPS Gukmun 2-pan Gibon Set: Character Book'' ({{korean|GURPS êµ­ë¬¸2í ê¸°ë³¸ì¸í¸: ìºë¦­í°ë¶}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Basic Set: Characters'', 4th edition ** ''GURPS Gukmun 2-pan Gibon Set: Campaign Book'' ({{korean|GURPS êµ­ë¬¸2í ê¸°ë³¸ì¸í¸: ìº íì¸ë¶}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Basic Set: Campaigns'', 4th edition ** ''GURPS Gukmun 2-pan Muhansegye'' ({{korean|GURPS êµ­ë¬¸2í ë¬´íì¸ê³}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Infinite Worlds'' ** ''GURPS Gukmun 2-pan Mabeop'' ({{korean|GURPS êµ­ë¬¸2í ë§ë²}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Magic'' for 4th edition ** ''GURPS Gukmun 2-pan Chosangneungryeok'' ({{korean|GURPS êµ­ë¬¸2í ì´ìë¥ë ¥}}) - Translation of ''GURPS Powers'' ** ''GURPS Gukmun 2-pan Dungeon Fantasy'' ({{korean|GURPS êµ­ë¬¸2í ëì ííì§}}) - Translation and compilation of from ''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 1'' to ''GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 4''
* ''GURPS Gukmun 2-pan Sylfiena'' ({{korean|GURPS êµ­ë¬¸2í ì¤í¼ìë}}) - The first original GURPS book in Korea. A low-mana fantasy campaign setting on the Earldom of Sylfiena for ''GURPS'', 4th edition.
==Independent products== *''GURPS Gulliver'', a fan-crafted expansion for ''GURPS 3e'' published online as an [[e-book]] by T Bone. It covers the physical aspects of the characters in greater detail than the basic rules. In April 2007, T Bone released a new version for ''GURPS 4e'', titled ''GULLIVER Mini'', covering only basic topics related to building and playing big and small creatures.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.gamesdiner.com/gulliver | title=GULLIVER supplement for the GURPS roleplaying game}}</ref> *''Historical Folks'', the collected material for a planned ''GURPS Historical Folks'' title, which Steve Jackson Games cancelled late in the production process. The compiler, Brian C. Smithson, organised the material and produced a free PDF compatible with ''GURPS 3e'' with the permission of the contributors.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://meekmok.com/sassy/ghf/ | title=Historical Folks | accessdate=2007-09-20}}</ref>
